reviewText:
Early Access Review

Time to finally review this aweome game. Well, theres the tl;dr answer, its awesome, go get it.
Now for a proper review...

Game Mechanics
Dinosystem is not your average, typical survival game. It is a deep, in-depth simulation that aims to simulate a prehistoric environment as accurately as possible. Trees aren't just static objects here, they will seed and die and burn. Same goes for sources of water, puddles will form, lakes will dry out in the summer. On top of that, the island you get to roam about in is procedurally generated, so you get to see a slightly different environment every time you start a new game. This level of depth in the mechanics is also shown with the player character and animal species on the island. Dinosaurs need to eat, sleep, drink and to reproduce. Different animals have different behaviours as well, for example, Ankylosaurs are more solitary animals, preffering to wander on their own or in very small groups, whereas Triceratops will move about in large herds.

Player Mechanics
Most survival games will have a basic hunger and thirst system, dinosystem takes this even further, you have to manage your stomach contents, drink and eat enough, not too little, not too much. Every action you perform tires out your character. Depending on your lifestyle, your character can grow to become fit and healthy, or they could get weaker, or fat. The way you play the game determines how your character develops.

Early Access
The game gets updated fairly regularly, roughly fortnightly to monthly. The developer is very dedicated to the project, he is very active on the forums and discussions and we talk pretty regularly about the game and stuff over steam (so, little disclaimer there). Coming very, very soon should be a really awesome update, followed by an even awesome-er one next month :D. So yeah, the commitment to the early access is really good and the developer has a clear plan for the order of the updates, so the finished release is planned out with all the content, there wont be any releasing early here. The finished game should be ready about late 2016.

Gameplay
A lot of the game revolves around keeping your character healthy and... not dead. There is a crafting system with a decent amount of items to craft with what you can salvage, the higher level of which normally require harder-to-get materials, such as dinosaur pelts. The combat and movement will feel strange at first, as it controls just a little differently to some other top-down games (mainly talking about the combat system there) but stick with it, because its worth it and becomes a really rewarding and fun experience. There are 4 very different seasons to each year (so, real life stuff) that force you to change your lifestyle to adapt to the new environmental conditions. Winter is, undoubtedly, the harshest of all the seasons due to the unrelenting cold.

Positive
- Deep, Complex Gameplay
- Nice Stylised Graphics
- Very Rewarding (especially when killing dinosaurs)
- Hardcore Mode

Negative
- Not that much content (dont forget, early access)

Final Rating: 9/10

WARNING: This is an early-access review, I am reviewing the game for what it is right now and NOT what it can be in the future. I may change my review once the game is out.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Day 3, I still don't know what to do. Day 5, I'm in a lot of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ situations. Day 6, I finished the tutorial. Day 7. I closed the game.

DinoSystem is a top down survival game set in the prehistoric era. You can create the world or have the game generate it for you. The aim of the game is for you to survive a densely populated area by gathering materials for survival, like stones, twigs, leaves, even hunt dinosaurs for food once you craft a good bow or a spear.

I love the idea of the game especially the character creation and the freedom to distribute stats, it's very interesting. Your character levels up according to what actions you take, similar to the oblivion series. I like the setting and its very cool to discover new things once you invest time reading the tutorial.

But that's it. I feel very bored at the start of the game, the visuals itself is a letdown and what's worse is the controls. The game is top down and you are using your WASD keys to move your character, which is very unresponsive and awkward especially if you want to turn your character in a different direction. I have played zombie shooter and other games which uses the same control mechanic, but those games feel right. The controls is fast and easy, but on this game, it feels slow. I would suggest to use of a point-click system, it will up the game atleast a hundred-fold and I could excuse the outdated visuals because I know the game has a lot of potential. The crafting and hunting system alone makes you wanna play for long hours. The discovery of new tools and new way of surviving and even thriving, I'm talking about planting your own crops, making your hut or even a tiny village. That's the kind of game I wanna invest in and would definitely give it another go.

Pros:
-Character Creation and Stats/Levelling System
-Crafting System
-Survival and Discovery
-Prehistoric Setting
-Sound is OK


Cons:
-Visual and Art Style
-CONTROLS
-Tutorial System isn't helpful and  hard to follow for people with less patience.

Suggestions:

-Change controls to point-click system
-Make the UI a lot larger
-Make an interactive tutorial system where the game is stopped for a moment for you to actually follow the tutorial before you are placed in the game where the time is running.
-Spice up the visuals a bit with some graphic overlays. Make the game look and feel like you are actually in a prehistoric era.
-Multiplayer ( LAN/Online)

Keep it up devs! As I've said the game has a lot of potential!=)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Triceratops are my new best buds, sticking with the herd warns me of danger in the distance.

Pros:
The environment and weather effects are incredibly rich. You see the fog of humidity, the haze of heat, tunnel-vision from starvation. When raining you need shelter to stop yourself getting wet, if its sunny you need shade. Mountains provide cover from savage winds. It is neither too harsh to batter new players, nor too soft to allow a lazy attitude.

In most survival games that feeling of fear you get from trying to survive against something stronger than you eventually subsides as you find ways to counter the most dangerous aspects. In this they seem to persist. I woke up to a HUGE adult T-Rex twice as large as my hut, luckily chasing down some other dinner. They will virtually always be more powerful, and the ever changing environment constantly gives new challenges.

This is at a level ready for release, calling it 'early access' was probably unnecessary prudence on the designers part. Though it does happily give me confidence that they will continue to improve it.
The price is generous, the quality of this game should be made clearer on the store page.

Improvements needed:
The tutorial was too wordy, all it needed was to say what the hotkeys were, so I needed to discover those myself.
Walking is too slow & awkward.
The left/right click UI is fairly cumbersome, the icons too small to understand.
Construction is fairly advanced, though could be fleshed out some with more options. The time needed to collect materials is just right (for that construction level).
Would be nice if the player could somehow influence the pooling of water (eg. digging lakes).

DinoSystem is a survival game with character development and crafting. At the moment it is a bit limited, but it has hte potential to be a great game. You can choose between two starting mods; one with a random world you get thrown into, the other where to develop the world as a god and then create your player in. The challenge is real, there's a pretty steep  learning curve, especially if you choose the random world and are unlucky enough to spawn near a T-rex.
There is certainly a lot of room for improvement and expansion on what is currently available, but as an early access game it. reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are many survival games, but DinoSystem stands out more than others due to being placed in an era which hasn’t been done by many in the survival genre. The era of the dinosaurs. Now, although I see lots of flaws in this game, it has lots of room for improvement, and it’s only in its early access stage. I really think once the story mode gets released, that there’s no doubt that this game will see some success.
To start off, looking at reviews on steam of this game and reading the description, I knew this game would be enjoyable right from the beginning. I am also a big fan of survival games. On the other hand, I feel like if someone didn’t have an initial judgement of the game before starting it, that they would find the menu very unappealing. The game itself is not unappealing, but the start menu does not spark an interest in my eyes. I feel like it could use some music, or sound effects for when you scroll through each menu option, or even just a better layout.
I started the game off with God mode and was immediately intrigued by the loading screen. You get to watch the world you will be playing in be generated right in front of your eyes! It gives you a real good idea on the size of the map. God Mode  really makes you feel like a “god”, giving you the ability to control the speed of time, the temperature, wind, and rain. You can also move plants and animals to give the map your own look and even creating surprising events (which will not be revealed to hide any spoilers). It also immediately stood out to me that there was no music in God Mode, and I was even more disappointed to find out there was no music in survival mode either. I really feel like music could be added to parts of the game to create more of an atmosphere as well as adding more intensity at certain parts.
And now onto survival mode. What an interesting approach to a video game. I’ve always been a big fan of games that make you feel like you’re in the game, creating real simulation and intense realism. The game does a good job at this, giving you access to interact with everything. Before we get into the gameplay itself, let’s talk about the character gameplay. There isn’t much you can do as for character “looks” but there’s lots you can do as for skills. You can make your character muscular, or you can make him fat. You can make him have low stamina and high endurance, which can all be improved in the game. As for the gameplay itself, literally everything you see can be used to build and/or craft something.  Also the fact that the world in survival mode is randomly generated every time you start a new game creates for a different gameplay every time. The beginning tutorial also makes it extremely easy for first time players to get into the game and know what to do almost right away.
As for the graphics, they could use some work, but I don’t judge a game by its graphics therefore games with low-quality graphics don’t bother me. I just know many other people find low quality graphics unappealing so it’s always nice to have a game that looks good. There was also a few times where dinosaurs were disappearing, or going through certain things that I would have to go around. Although these are negative points, these are all small fixes that have no “game ruining” factor. Judging by the entirety of this game, the developers have all of my beliefs that this game will just get better and better.
Lastly, the sound effects. The sound designers did a great job with the sound production on this game. The sounds really help create an atmosphere. I got a really good kick at the animation and sound effects of when your character is shivering. The only that might be wrong with the sound effects is the birds chirping. I’m not sure if there were birds during the dinosaur era, but I may be completely wrong.
All in all, DinoSystem was a decent game. If you are fan of games in the survival genre, you might be interested in this one! The price is a little steep but I’m sure it will be well worth the money when it’s out of its early access stage and when the story mode gets added. I give this game a rating of 6 out of 10, but I feel like if I were to write a review for this game in another few months that my rating for the game would be higher. It still needs some work, but the developers have done a good job with the game already and I know the final job will be fantastic. I look forward to seeing what happens with this game in the future!

DinoSystem is a very detailed Game and even if you don't pick this game up yet keep your eye on it!

The game currently features 2 modes, survival and God Mode.

I haven't played as much as the game runs at about 10 fps since my machine isn't great but I had enough time to witness the great potential this game has and I hope the developer creates something amazing with this.

Survival Mode

This mode should be familiar to people who play survival games since the main objective is survive but in this game the way you survive is much more complex and though provoking. You aren't just some guy on an island with a million dinosaurs that respawn, you are 1 guy with a limited amount of dinosaurs. These dinosaurs will reproduce and make more dinosaurs, if you allow them, you can wipe out an entire species by stopping them from mating by either killing all males/females or just slaughtering them all.

You will have to use a crafting system similar to Stranded Deep since you have to carry or drag items over to you and then interact with them. You will have to be wary of different conditions since the game has a weather and climate system so you must adapt and fast.

God Mode

In God mode you are...Well God! You control the climate, weather and can even maniuplate object and animals by moving them. There isn't much to do but you can mess around by watching the dinosaurs live their lives or even create a character and hop in.

Conclusion

The game as of this review [23/12/2015] isn't entirely worth the asking price unless you really like this sort of thing, I would recommend you wait otherwise or check some videos to see if it interests you. The game has great potential and I hope this will become a prime example of why Early Access can be a great thing!

It took me all game night and half the game day to get a fire going and then it rained it's like a survival game from the book of Job.
